Graphical abstract g-C3N3 not only has high content of pyridine nitrogen, but also has a special two-dimensional porous structure, which is an ideal diatomic catalytic host materials. In this work, homonuclear and heteronuclear dual-atom catalysts (DACs, TM-TM@g-C3N3, TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) were constructed using single-layer g-C3N3 as the carrier material of DACs, and their potential as sulfur-hosting materials and electrocatalytic materials for lithium-sulfur batteries was explored through first principles comprehensively. The results show that the coupling between the two metal atoms in heteronuclear DACs can regulate the spin state of each other's d-electrons, so that the anchoring and catalytic effects of heteronuclear DACs on polysulfide are more excellent than that of homonuclear DACs. Co-Mn@g-C3N3, when utilized as the cathode material in lithium-sulfur batteries, offers exceptional properties due to the hybridization between Mn2+ high-spin state d electron and Co2+ half-filled dz 2 orbital. This unique interaction not only enables the polysulfide to exhibit the lowest Gibbs free energy during conversion, but also results in the lowest reaction energy barrier of 0.26 eV for the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S. Furthermore, it is found that when 3d transition metal atoms act as heteronuclear DACs, the coupling between metal ions with high-spin states at the active site and metal ions with empty orbitals or half-full d-electrons has the most significant catalytic effect on polysulfides. Keywords Dual-atom catalysts Single-layer g-C3N3 Cathode material Lithium-sulfur batteries Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are one of the most promising rechargeable energy storage devices, and the 16-electrons transfer from the cathode active sulfur substance (S8) to Li2S and the non-topological reaction mechanism of the electrode material achieve a high theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh/g [1,2]. However, the low conductivity of the sulfur cathode, the shuttle effect of polysulfide (LiPSs), and the slow kinetics of sulfur reduction (SRR) reaction still hinder the practical application of LSBs [3–6]. Therefore, the development of sulfur-hosting materials with excellent anchoring and catalytic effects on LiPSs has long been the research topic of many scholars. Since the single atom catalyst (SACs) was proposed in 2011, it has been widely developed. Although there is no traditional metal–metal bond in the coordination mode, the unique coordination configuration of single atom makes SACs have very high catalytic activity in almost all types of catalytic reactions such as hydrogenation reaction, water vapor conversion, photocatalysis and electrocatalysis [7]. However, in SACs, the contact area between the single atom and the carrier is small, the interaction is weak, and the load is relatively low. The microstructure of SACs not only changes the activity, but also changes the selectivity of different products [8]. Therefore, it is crucial to manipulate the catalyst structure with high precision and design catalysts with different active sites. On the basis of single atomic sites, more complex systems such as diatomic sites, multiatomic sites and atomic interfaces have been conceived and constructed to improve the catalytic activity of catalysts [9]. Among them, diatomic catalysts (DACs) have become a new frontier in heterogeneous catalysis because they can produce synergistic effect between adjacent active sites, and improve catalytic activity while maintaining high utilization rate, good selectivity, atomic dispersion and high stability [10]. Compared with SACs, DACs can increase the number of single atom load and thus increase the number of active centers [11]. Existing studies have shown that catalysts usually involve the hybridization of d orbitals of transition metal atoms with adsorbed LiPSs intermediates, reducing the reaction energy barrier by changing their electronic structure. For example, Xun et al. [12] prepared hollow carbon spheres supported by Fe-Co atomically dispersed DACs with bi-functional catalytic activity as sulfur hosting materials for LSBs. The unique two-site structure not only enhances the anchoring effect of LiPSs, but also accelerates the transformation of LiPSs and promotes the decomposition of Li2S. Pan et al. [13] adopted the first principles, using single-layer C2N as DACs carrier, and introducing Cu, V, Co, Fe, and Ni homonuclear dimers to form sulfur hosting materials for LSBs. The results show that these DACs not only have excellent anchoring ability for polysulfide, but also reduce the free energy of sulfur reduction reaction to 1.22 ∼ 1.46 eV, and the decomposition energy barrier of electrochemical conversion to 0.82 ∼ 1.29 eV, which effectively improves the conversion efficiency during discharge/charging. Further research on DACs has focused on other areas, such as strong REDOX reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), atmospheric nitrogen reduction (NRR) and carbon dioxide reduction (CO2RR) [9]. Xing et al. [14] prepared DACs with the novel dual-nuclear active site structure of Co2NxCy, and the activity of the ORR reaction was about 12 times higher than that of the traditional CoN4 site. Fe-Cu diatomic site catalyst N4Fe-CuN3 with unique coordination structure prepared by Feng et al. [15]. The synergistic effect of Fe-Cu diatoms effectively regulates the position of the d-band center, which can effectively reduce the formation of *COOH intermediates and the energy barrier of *CO desorption, and promote the generation of CO. Carriers play a crucial role in the study of DASs due to the size effect and ligand effect of catalysts. Metal oxides were used as carriers of SACs and DACs in earlier years, but due to the difficulty of preparation, there were few and insufficient researches [16]. As the carrier materials of DACs are relatively limited, rational use of the quantum confinement effect of porous materials may be an effective strategy to overcome the above problems [17]. In the present study, two-dimensional CN materials with flat surface structure have received extensive attention due to their low dimension and special electronic properties [18,19], and can be used as carriers for SACs and DACs catalysts due to their excellent spintronic properties [20–23]. Among them, g-C3N3 not only has a relatively high content of pyridine nitrogen, but also has a special two-dimensional porous structure, and the structure is stable [24]. Therefore, g-C3N3 is expected to be an excellent carrier of metal single atom and dimer. In recent years, it has been found that the orbital hybridization between the d-orbital of the transition metal and the p-orbital of the S atom can enhance the bonding strength when the carbon nitrogen compounds containing transition metals interact with LiPSs. Therefore, different unpaired electron filling states on the leading orbits of dz 2, dxz, and dyz can produce different spin state, changing the interaction with LiPSs. Here, based on the first principles, this work proposed to study the structural and electronic properties of DACs dimers of homonuclear and heteronuclear transition metals (TM-TM@g-C3N3, TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) and their potential as sulfur-hosting materials for LSBs, using g-C3N3 as a carrier. The results show that the catalytic activity of heteronuclear diatomic dimer DACs on polysulfide is superior to that of homonuclear diatomic dimer DACs. Due to the synergistic effect between the high-spin state of the d electron of Mn2+ and the half-full state of the dz 2 orbital of Co2+, Co-Mn@g-C3N3, when used as the positive electrode material of LSBs, not only can the polysulfide have the lowest Gibbs free energy during the conversion process, The reaction energy barrier of Li2S2 to Li2S is the lowest (0.26 eV). Further study on the electronic structure shows that when 3d transition metal atoms act as heteronuclear diatomic catalysts, the coupling between metal ions with high-spin states and metal atoms with half-full d-electrons at the active site has the most significant catalytic effect on polysulfide. 2 Result 2.1 Structural and electronic structure of TM-TM@g-C3N3 Fig. 1 shows the stable configuration of TM-TM@g-C3N3, bader charge analysis (see Table S1 for specific data), and electron localization function (ELF). As shown in the figure, each TM atom is bound to two N atoms [15], and only Co-Co@g-C3N3, Fe-Mn@ g-C3N3 and Co-Ni@g-C3N3 are completely planar structures. TM atoms in other structures have protrprotrations to varying degrees, and the TM-N bond length decreases gradually with the increase of metal atomic number (Table S2). This is due to differences in the size of the TM ion, the available d electrons, and the nature of the bond [24]. The results of bader charge analysis showed a pattern of Fe-Mn > Mn-Mn > Fe-Co > Co-Mn > Co-Co > Co-Ni > Fe-Fe > Ni-Mn > Fe-Ni > Ni-Ni. In the homonuclear dimer DACs, the number of electrons transferred from Mn-Mn to g-C3N3 was the highest (1.25 |e|), while the number of electrons transferred from Ni-Ni to g-C3N3 was the lowest (0.86 |e|). In the heteronuclear dimer DACs, the maximum number of electrons transferred from Fe-Mn to g-C3N3 is 1.37 |e|, and Fe-Mn > Mn-Mn > Fe-Fe. It can be seen that Fe-Mn dimers can promote electron transfer between each other. The map of ELF shows that in the homonuclear dimer DACs, the electron cloud density between metal atoms decreases significantly with the increase of atomic number. In the heteronuclear dimer DACs, a similar phenomenon is also shown, that is, the larger the sum of the atomic numbers of the two metals, the smaller the electron cloud between the atoms. Moreover, in the heteronuclear dimer DACs with adjacent atomic numbers (such as Fe-Mn, Fe-Co, Co-Ni), the electron cloud is mainly concentrated in the center of the bimetallic atoms. In the non-adjacent heteronuclear dimer DACs (such as Co-Mn, Ni-Mn, Fe-Ni), the electron cloud is mainly biased to the side with the smaller atomic number, and the greater the atomic number distance, the more obvious this phenomenon is. The reason for the above phenomenon is that the number of d electrons of Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+ and Ni2+ is 5, 6, 7 and 8, respectively. With the increase of the number of d electrons, the binding of the nucleus on the electrons is enhanced, and the degree of electron localization is stronger. Two metal atoms with the same or adjacent atomic numbers have similar electron binding abilities. Among them, the four d-orbitals of Ni2+ are full states, and the electron localization is the strongest, which is difficult to contribute electrons. Fig. 2 shows the projected density of state (PDOS) TM-TM@g-C3N3 and the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Populations (COHP), and Fig. S1 shows the detailed PDOS of d-orbitals of transition metal atoms. In homonuclear dimer DACs, the PDOS of N atomic shows obvious delocalization, and the density of transition metal d-orbital PDOS shows obvious localization, which is due to the weak electron localization of s-orbitals and p-orbitals, and the strong electron localization of 3d-orbitals. As can be seen from Fig. S1, the valence band tops of the d orbitals of TM in Fe-Fe@g-C3N3, Co-Co@g-C3N3 and Ni-Ni@g-C3N3 are contributed by the dxz/z 2, dxz/yz and dxy/yz/z 2 orbitals, which are double and triple degeneracies, respectively. The valence band top of the d orbital of Mn in Mn-Mn@g-C3N3 is contributed by five orbitals at the same time, and no obvious orbital splitting occurs. The density curve of N atomic states overlaps with the density curve of d-orbital states of metal atoms. The d-orbital of TM is obviously coupled with the p-orbital of N atom, which indicates that there is a solid bond cooperation between TM and N atom. Among them, the coupling effect between Ni and N atoms is the strongest, the coupling effect between Fe and Co atoms and N atoms is similar and weaker than Ni atoms, and the coupling effect between Mn and N atoms is the weakest. At the same time, the crystal orbital Hamiltonian shows that TM and N atoms bond at low energy levels, and the bond between the two TM atoms occurs near the Fermi level. This is because the d-orbital electrons of Mn2+ only have upper spin states, and according to the Hund rule [25] and Pauli exclusion principle [26], its d-orbitals are half full and in high-spin states. The d-orbital electrons of Fe2+, Co2+ and Ni2+ atoms have two spin states, spin up and spin down, and belong to the low spin state. Therefore, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+ and N atoms are more likely to form bonding orbitals, while Mn2+ are more likely to form antibonding orbitals. Compared with homonuclear dimer DACs, the peak density of metal atoms' d-orbital states in heteronuclear dimer DACs decreases, and the d-electron localization decreases. The -COHP peaks of TM-N bonds were increased, and the bond interaction was enhanced. Compared with the state densities of Fe-Fe and Co-Co, the peak of the d-orbital state density in Fe-Co@g-C3N3 disappears near the fermi level, and the peak value at the low energy level also decreases, but the peak width increases. Meanwhile, the bonding level of Fe-Co in -COHP is lower than that of Fe-Fe and Co-Co. The valence band tops of d-orbitals of Fe2+ in Fe-Co@g-C3N3, Fe-Ni@g-C3N3 and Fe-Mn@g-C3N3 are contributed by dz 2, dxz and dyz/z 2, respectively. The valence band tops of d-orbitals of Co2+ in Fe-Co@g-C3N3, Co-Ni@g-C3N3 and Co-Mn@g-C3N3 are contributed by dz 2, dz 2 and dxz, respectively. The d valence band tops of Ni atoms in Fe-Ni@g-C3N3, Co-Ni@g-C3N3 and Ni-Mn@g-C3N3 are all contributed by dxz/yz/z 2. -COHP shows that the electrons between metal atoms and pyridine nitrogen are all in bonding states and all occur between −8 and −6 eV. In both homonuclear dimer and heteronuclear dimer, there are coupling phenomena between the two atoms to different degrees. The orbital energy level of coupling between metal atoms in homonuclear dimer is higher, while the orbital energy level of coupling between metal atoms in heteronuclear dimer is lower, indicating that the DACs configuration of heteronuclear dimer is more conducive to the stability of the structure. For Fe2+, ICOHP coupled with heteronuclear atom is weakened. For Co2+, ICOHP is enhanced after coupling with Ni2+ and Mn2+, while ICOHP is weakened between Co2+ and Fe2+. The ICOHP of the Ni-Fe bond is stronger than that of the Ni-Ni bond and weaker than that of the Ni-Mn bond. In a word, the coupling between Co-Ni is the strongest (ICOHP = -2.64 eV). It can be seen that the degeneracy and splitting of d-orbitals change after the coupling between heteronuclear dimer. It is mainly show in the disappearance of double and triple degeneracy from homonuclear dimer DACs to heteronuclear dimer DACs. This will lead to the conversion of electrons from low-spin states to high-spin states, enhancing activity of electron. In addition, Mulliken population analuysis (Table S3) data show that after TM bonds with N atoms, the number of d electrons is greater than the theoretical number of d electrons of its 2-valent ions. This shows that TM and N atoms share electron and orbitals rather than just simple ionic bonds. In general, since ions with a larger number of charges have a smaller radius, the closer the ligand is to the central ion results in an increase in repulsion. Therefore, the more charge in the same period element, the greater the ligand-field splitting parameter. Therefore, the crystal field splitting energy of the four elements in this paper shows the law of Mn2+<Ni2+<Co2+<Fe2+. Because they are similar to tetragonal crystal fields, the ligand-field splitting parameter is less than pairing energy, so they are weak fields, electrons are in high spin configuration, g-C3N3 and metal atoms belong to outer orbital complexes, crystal field energy is high, and electronic activity is strong. The coordination environment for a transition metal atom anchored by two nitrogen atoms can be approximated to a C4v crystal field, with five d-orbitals splitting into four d states: dz 2, dxy, dxz/yz (double degenerate), and dx 2 -y 2. The dz 2 orbitals are hybridized with the pz orbitals of S to form σ and σ* bonds with strong splitting energy. The double degeneracies dxz/yz hybridizes with the px/y orbitals to form relatively weak π and π* bonds. The dxy and dx 2 -y 2 orbitals are not active compared to the other d-states and are considered non-bonding orbitals [4]. 2.2 Adsorption structure and adsorption energy In LSBs, the orthorhombic α-S8 at room temperature is chosen as the model of crystalline sulfur, which is a crown-like ring structure. This section focuses on the analysis of the reaction free energy of polysulfides in heteronuclear dimer DACs. As shown in the Fig. 7 (a). The process from S8 to Li2S is exothermic on the surface of all six structures and can be spontaneous. A certain energy barrier needs to be overcome on other surfaces. Fortunately, only 0.03 eV reaction energy barrier needs to be overcome on Co-Ni@g-C3N3 surface, while larger reaction potential barrier needs to be overcome on the other three surfaces. The liquid-phase reaction Li2S6 to Li2S4 is flat, with the lowest Gibbs free energy of −0.10 eV (Fe-Co@g-C3N3). The solid–liquid conversion process from Li2S4 to Li2S2 is the rate-limiting step in the charge–discharge process, which is also the main reason for the decrease of the utilization rate of active substances and the formation of dead sulfur [17,35]. It occurs spontaneously on Co-Ni@g-C3N3 and Fe-Co@g-C3N3 with Gibbs free energies of −0.12 eV and −0.05 eV, respectively. Other surfaces are endothermic reactions. The solid state reaction of Li2S2 to Li2S is endothermic on all substrates, among which the lowest Gibbs free energy is Co-Mn@g-C3N3, which is only 0.26 eV. To sum up, as shown in Fig. 7(b), at the diatomic site, such as Co-Mn@g-C3N3, Fe-Co@g-C3N3, and Co-Ni@g-C3N3, the high energy d-orbital of one transition metal ion (e.g. TM2) has a single d electron. And adjacent transition metal ions (such as TM1) have empty d orbitals or half-full d orbitals. When the two are coupled, the single electron in TM2 will transition to the empty d-orbital or the half-full d-orbital in TM1, which makes the catalyst have higher activity. 3 Conclusion In summary, the performance of a series of TM (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni) dimers embedded in monolayer g-C3N3 for the LiPSs anchored and catalytic conversion as polar hosts for cathodes is systematically investigated by DFT calculation. The results reveal that the monolayer g-C3N3 serves as a substrate to stabilize TM atoms, while the TM dimers dictate the metallic electronic structure. Due to the presence of TM-S bonds, all DACs have excellent anchoring effects on LiPSs. The electron regulation between the two metallic atoms in the heteronuclear dimer results in the superiority of the heteronuclear dimer DACs in catalysis. Among them, Co-Mn@g-C3N3 has the best catalytic effect for the REDOX reaction of LiPSs. Moreover, due to the d-orbital coupling of the bimetallic atoms in Co-Mn@g-C3N3, Fe-Co@g-C3N3 and Co-Ni@g-C3N3, the single electron on the dz 2 orbital of Co2+ can transition between the two atoms, so that its catalytic effect is obviously better than that of other dimer DACs. Therefore, when 3d transition metal atoms act as heteronuclear diatomic catalysts, the coupling between metal ions with high spin states at the active site and metal atoms with empty orbitals or half-full d-electrons has the most significant catalytic effect on LiPSs. In addition, the hybridization of the p-orbital of S in LiPSs with the d-orbital of the transition metal to form TM-S bond can promote the REDOX reaction of LiPSs, so the heteronuclear diatomic system has more possibilities and controllability when catalyzed by LiPSs. This work offers theoretical guidance for the synthesis of metal catalysts and greatly reduces the workload of selecting TM atoms, which provides opportunities for the DACs catalytic materials in the development of LSBs. 3.1 Calculation method Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations are carried out as implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [36]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [37,38] is used for our calculations. Projected augmented wave (PAW) method [39,40] is employed using an energy cut-off of 450 eV to describe the electronic wave functions. We have adopted GGA + U method to properly describe the strongly correlated electrons in the partially filled d-orbitals [41]. All the calculations are carried our using GGA + U method [42]. Here, the delocalized s and p electrons are defined by the GGA method and the localized d electrons are described by the Coulomb and exchange corrections. This method improves both the excited-state (e.g. energy gaps) and the ground-state properties (e.g. magnetic moments and interatomic exchange parameters). We have used correlation energy (U) of 4 eV and exchange energy (J) of 1 eV for TM 3d-orbitals. These U and J values have been well tested experimentally as well as theoretically in similar systems [43–45]. We have taken a vacuum of 30 Å along the z-axis to avoid any interaction between the two adjacent layers. A Monkhorst-pack [46] generated set of 3 × 3 × 1 K-point is used to get the minimum energy structure. The convergence criteria for energy and force are set at 10-5 eV and 10-2 eV/Å, respectively. Bader charge analysis is performed [47–49] with the help of the Henkelman programme [50] using near-grid algorithm refine-edge method to understand the charge transfer process between the atoms. To analyze the electronic structure, Crystal Occupation Hamilton Population (COHP) analysis was performed on LOBSTER software [51–53]. CRediT authorship contribution statement Wei Dong: . coredata.dc:description: g-C3N3 not only has high content of pyridine nitrogen, but also has a special two-dimensional porous structure, which is an ideal diatomic catalytic host materials. In this work, homonuclear and heteronuclear dual-atom catalysts (DACs, TM-TM@g-C3N3, TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) were constructed using single-layer g-C3N3 as the carrier material of DACs, and their potential as sulfur-hosting materials and electrocatalytic materials for lithium-sulfur batteries was explored through first principles comprehensively. The results show that the coupling between the two metal atoms in heteronuclear DACs can regulate the spin state of each other's d-electrons, so that the anchoring and catalytic effects of heteronuclear DACs on polysulfide are more excellent than that of homonuclear DACs. Co-Mn@g-C3N3, when utilized as the cathode material in lithium-sulfur batteries, offers exceptional properties due to the hybridization between Mn2+ high-spin state d electron and Co2+ half-filled dz 2 orbital. This unique interaction not only enables the polysulfide to exhibit the lowest Gibbs free energy during conversion, but also results in the lowest reaction energy barrier of 0.26 eV for the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S. Furthermore, it is found that when 3d transition metal atoms act as heteronuclear DACs, the coupling between metal ions with high-spin states at the active site and metal ions with empty orbitals or half-full d-electrons has the most significant catalytic effect on polysulfides.
coredata.dc:title: Heterokaryotic transition-metal dimers embedded monolayer g-C3N3 as promising anchoring and electrocatalytic materials for lithium-sulfur battery: First-principles calculations
